to change written or spoken words into another language
Translate the text from Italian into English.
Dagda, an ancient Irish deity, literally translates as ‘the good god’.
if one thing translates into another, the second thing happens as a result of the first
A small increase in local spending will translate into a big rise in property tax.
to mean the same as something else
These rates translate into a return of 8.5% for dollar investors.
to change something, or be changed, from one form into another
Jokes often don’t translate well into print.
the danger of translating your emotions into actions
to be used in a new situation, or to make something do this
It’s amazing how well the play has been translated to film.
translate.translation[0].note_box[0].sec: to change written or spoken words into another language
She has translated a number of his books.
Michael Meyer translated the play from the original Norwegian.
Can you translate this into French?
to change what someone is saying into another language, as they are speaking
No one in our tour group spoke Spanish so we had to ask the guide to interpret.
We'll have to find someone who speaks Chinese to interpret the questions and answers for our guests.
I had to interpret for my boss on the last trip to Japan.
to translate something into another language, especially a few words or a short piece of writing
I've written a message for Fabio. Could you put it into Italian for me?
I had to put a list of Japanese words into English.
to change one currency into another
A strong dollar reduces the value of overseas profits when they are translated back into dollars.
The company sustained losses as revenue was translated from weak dollars to strong marks.
to change something from one form to another, especially to produce a final result
This task previously required an extra machine to translate computer files.
£100m of private investment should translate into 5,000 new inner-city jobs.
The production team translates the architect’s specifications into high-quality systems.
